advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>March 1983 advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The big differences between the Epson HX-20 Notebook Computer (on the left) and the Apple Computer (on the right) are 1) the HX-20 doesn't need a power cord, 2) the HX-20 weights only about four pounds, and 3) the HX-20 costs a lot less money... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This painting was the first and the best known MITS Altair advert. It was created by Kim Behm who has since become a well-known artist. At the first beginning of the personal computers era, this advert seems to be saying: In a near future, everybody around the world will have access to a personal computer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''God created the world, DAI put it under CP/M''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #8</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>Upgrade kit to transform a Spectrum into a Spectrum +<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MITS BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.). <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>

computer.description: The Atari 4160 STe is an Atari 520 STe with 4 MB of RAM. It was never marketed and was built by Atari for the developpers. It had a special version of TOS, version 1.6 (the Atari ST Operating System), with less bugs than in the final version !

emulator.description: Hatari is an Atari ST emulator for Linux, BSD, BeOS, Mac OS X and other systems that are supported by the SDL library. More precisely, Hatari is an adaption of the WinSTon source code to the SDL library.
emulator.name: Hatari

item.description: 170Mb Quantum hard-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 170MB QUANTUM HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This unit has an ICD Host Adapter.</blockquote>
Atari Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote>This hard-drive has a 30Mb capacity.</blockquote>

Inside the Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seagate MFM 30 MB hard-disk Type ST-238<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(3)</b> Logical board<br> <b>(4)</b> Power and disk access LED's<br></blockquote>

Atari universal modem||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI UNIVERSAL MODEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SX212 modem was one of the rare Atari peripherals that could be used with all the Atari computers range, from the 400/800 series up to the Falcon. It had both the Atari I/O ports for the 8-bit systems and a standard RS-232 connector for ST's<br><br> It was a 300/1200 baud modem compatible with the well-known Hayes 'AT' commands.<br> Cable and software was sold separately, depending of the computer used. </blockquote>

SML-804|||Laser printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SML-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer</strong><br><blockquote>The SLM-804 was actually a Kyocera F1000 printer but without neither on-board processor and memory nor buttons other than the on/off switch. It was first delivered with the Mega ST but could be connected on all of the ST series computers through a dedicated interface box.<br> The printer used the processing power and the RAM memory of the ST computer for printing at 8 pages per minute and 300 DPI. The paper tray held 250 sheets.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Francois Michaud</b> who donated us this printer.</p></blockquote>

SMLC-804|||Laser printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SMLC-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface allowed the SML-804 printer to be connected to any Atari ST holding at least 1 MB RAM.</blockquote>

computer.name: 4160 Ste
